NEW DELHI: India and Australia are set to cross swords in the marquee Border-Gavaskar Trophy with the first Test starting in Perth on November 22. The two sides will clash in five Test matches that are instrumental in the ICC World Test Championship 2023-25.Team India would be eyeing their third successive Test series win on the trot in Australia and the Aussies would be looking to go all guns blazing to stop the Indians in their bid to reclaim the Border-Gavaskar Trophy.India need to win four Tests in Australia to directly qualify for the World Test Championships final that is scheduled to be held at Lord's in June 2025.Australia have not defeated India in a home Test series since 2014-15, losing both the 2018-19 and 2020-21 series.Australia defeated India in the World Test Championship final and in the 50-overs World Cup final last year.This will the first five-Test series between the two sides in more than 30 years.Here is the full schedule of the Test series:Perth will host the first Test of the series from November 22.The match is scheduled to start at 7:50 AM IST.The series' second game will take place as a day-night Test in Adelaide on December 6.The match is scheduled to start at 9:30 AM IST.The third game will take place at the Gabba in Brisbane on December 14.The match is scheduled to start at 5:50 AM IST.The fourth game will take place in Melbourne on December 26 - traditionally known as the Boxing Day Test.The match is scheduled to start at 5:00 AM IST.The series will conclude with the customary New Year's Test in Sydney that will start from January 3.The match is scheduled to start at 5:00 AM IST.The unavailability of captain Rohit Sharma and No. 3 bat Shumban Gill (fracture in the finger) from the first Test against Australia forced the BCCI on Sunday to ask top-order batsman Devdutt Padikkal, who was touring with the India A squad for two four-day matches, to stay back as a batting back-up.Pace spearhead and vice-captain Jasprit Bumrah will captain India in absence of Rohit, who informed the BCCI that he needed more time with his wife after the birth of their second child earlier this week.Paddikal will be added to the 18-member squad in Rohit's place for the first Test match at the Opus Stadium in Perth.Rohit Sharma (C), Jasprit Bumrah (VC), Yashasvi Jaiswal, Abhimanyu Easwaran, Shubman Gill, Virat Kohli , KL Rahul, Rishabh Pant (WK), Sarfaraz Khan, Dhruv Jurel (WK), R Ashwin, Ravindra Jadeja , Mohammed Siraj, Akash Deep, Prasidh Krishna, Harshit Rana, Nitish Kumar Reddy, Washington SundarMukesh Kumar, Navdeep Saini, Khaleel Ahmed (replaced by Yash Dayal) Pat Cummins (Capt.), Scott Boland, Alex Carey, Josh Hazlewood, Travis Head, Josh Inglis, Usman Khawaja, Marnus Labuschagne, Nathan Lyon, Mitchell Marsh, Nathan McSweeney, Steve Smith, Mitchell Starc

NEW DELHI: The IPL 2025 auction witnessed historic spending as franchises splurged on marquee players, creating unforgettable moments. Rishabh Pant emerged as the most expensive player in IPL history, securing a jaw-dropping Rs 27 crore deal with Lucknow Super Giants (LSG).Punjab Kings (PBKS) made headlines as well, signing former Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) captain Shreyas Iyer for Rs 26.75 crore, briefly making him the costliest player before Pant's record-breaking deal.Adding to the drama, KKR surprised everyone by re-signing all-rounder Venkatesh Iyer for Rs 23.75 crore, cementing his value as a franchise cornerstone.Another standout moment came when 13-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi joined Rajasthan Royals (RR) for Rs 1.10 crore, making headlines as the youngest player ever to be signed.As many as 182 players were signed in the two-day mega auction in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, with total spending by the ten franchises reaching Rs 639.15 crore. Out of the total players, 62 were overseas cricketers.Day 2 of the auction brought further excitement as experienced Indian pacers found themselves in high demand.Veteran seamer Bhuvneshwar Kumar, out of the national setup for two years, secured an impressive Rs 10.75 crore deal with Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB), showcasing his enduring value in T20 cricket.Mumbai Indians (MI) snapped up Deepak Chahar for Rs 9.25 crore despite concerns over his fitness, while Delhi Capitals (DC) used their RTM card to retain Mukesh Kumar for Rs 8 crore. Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) continued their strategic spending, investing Rs 8 crore in Akash Deep, with RCB signing Krunal Pandya for Rs 5.75 crore and RR acquiring Tushar Deshpande for Rs 6.50 crore.International players also enjoyed strong representation in the auction. South Africa’s Marco Jansen secured a Rs 7 crore deal with PBKS, while New Zealand’s Trent Boult fetched Rs 12.5 crore from MI, reflecting the premium placed on fast bowling. The auction also highlighted the demand for veteran leadership, as Faf du Plessis joined DC for Rs 2 crore.Despite several big names going unsold, the auction reaffirmed the IPL's emphasis on emerging and proven talent, especially from India, driving up prices and setting the stage for an exciting 2025 season.

What Happened Suddenly Between Travis Kelce and Patrick Mahomes That Led to Such a Confession

Brotherhood is pretty common in sports like the NFL, as many say the team thrives in such a situation. Kansas City Chiefs, which has become one of the strongest teams and has remained undefeated mostly throughout the season is a living proof of this theory. Out of all the players in the team, there are two such players who have stayed with each other at the highest of highs and lowest of lows - Kansas City Chiefs tight end, Travis Kelce and the quarterback Patrick Mahomes. Recently, both of them also had to deal with an unsettling incident that involved robbery and burglary of both their houses, just days apart from each other. No matter what the situation has been, these two have always remained thick with each other and now even the love of their lives are also close to each other. Kelce’s girlfriend Taylor Swift has been spotted hanging out with Mahomes’ wife Brittany quite a lot of times.Apart from being a star on the field, Kelce also hosts a podcast called “New Heights” with his older brother and the former NFL Star of the Philadelphia Eagles, Jason Kelce. Their podcast is all about brotherhood, sharing stories around the NFL and their personal lives.Recently, on an episode of the “New Heights”, Travis Kelce admitted something personal that many were not prepared for - him not being able to connect with Patrick Mahomes anymore. This caught many by surprise as Kelce went on to admit that he is just not “on the same page” with Mahomes. Travis said, “Right now, for whatever reason, I can’t find my way in the end zone. I’m just not on the same page as Pat. It’s f—–g frustrating, that’s for damn sure.”Also Read: NFL playoff is set—but with the underdogs closing in, the NFL playoffs could look totally different by January Such a candid admission has raised many questions in the minds of fans since Kansas City Chiefs is one such team that has always thrived on teamwork and the bond players share with one other. So what would be the result if the two star players are not being able to connect with each other.With the playoffs near, this has worried people and rightly so. While the reason behind such an honest admission by Kelce is not really known, Mahomes has not come out in public to speak about it. At the end of the day, the Kansas City Chiefs is a really strong team so one should not judge their capability even if the brotherhood is affected at the moment.

Kelce said that he is just not “on the same page” with Mahomes. Such a candid admission has raised many questions in the minds of fans since Kansas City Chiefs is one such team that thrives on teamwork.

With only six retentions allowed, franchises spent a staggering Rs 639.15 crore to acquire 182 players, including 62 overseas stars, during the two-day event.This overhaul saw the end of several iconic long-term associations, with players like Bhuvneshwar Kumar Rishabh Pant , and Jos Buttler switching teams.Notable moves included Pant’s record-breaking Rs 27 crore transfer to Lucknow Super Giants and Bhuvneshwar’s return to Royal Challengers Bengaluru. The auction reshaped team dynamics, setting the stage for an exciting 2025 season.Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Sunrisers Hyderabad’s all-time leading wicket-taker, ended his 11-year stint with the franchise. The pacer, who joined SRH in 2014, was acquired by Royal Challengers Bengaluru for Rs 10.75 crore, marking his return to the team where his IPL journey began in 2009.Rishabh Pant, the former Delhi Capitals captain, became the most expensive player in IPL history, joining Lucknow Super Giants for a record Rs 27 crore. After nine years at DC, Pant is expected to take on a leadership role at LSG, replacing KL Rahul, who moved to DC for Rs 14 crore.Mumbai Indians parted ways with wicketkeeper-batter Ishan Kishan after seven years. Kishan, with 2644 IPL runs, was picked up by Sunrisers Hyderabad for Rs 11.25 crore.Royal Challengers Bengaluru pacer Mohammed Siraj, a vital part of their bowling attack, joined Gujarat Titans for Rs 12.25 crore. Siraj exits RCB with 93 wickets in as many matches.English star Jos Buttler, a cornerstone of Rajasthan Royals’ batting lineup, will now represent Gujarat Titans after being bought for Rs 15.75 crore. Article Title: Deion Sanders and Ex-Wife Keep distance during Senior Day celebration for sons Shedeur and Shilo
Article Text:
Credit: Getty Images

Shedeur Sanders Brings Both Parents Together on Senior Day



"Home Game Finale” A Special Day with the Fam at Colorado

With that, here is the best-sounding version ever: A family thing in which Colorado Buffaloes quarterback Shedeur Sanders orchestrated a grand event on Senior Day. The kid really wanted to share the spotlight with his parents because he's always been raised by his father, the great Deion Sanders . The planning showed behind-the-scenes to the public via a video uploaded on the official Shilo Sanders YouTube channel. With Shedeur wanting to bring in her mom Pilar to the celebration even when things are mixed up at home, it's fair to say he somehow managed to convince her to come onto the field.Shedeur Sanders, the star quarterback for Colorado, made senior day a signature time with both his parents being present. He wanted his mother, Pilar Sanders, to witness the event and so he walked into the stands to convince her to come despite the fact his father - head coach Deion Sanders - was also there. This touching gesture was highlighted in a video shared on Shilo Sanders' YouTube channel, where Shilo humorously remarked, “My brother [Shedeur] just got my mom from the stands cause of the senior day, and we didn’t know we had to walk. They’re not gonna. That’s like World War III trying to get them to walk together.”Deion's sons, Shedeur and Shilo, were walking with their father on the field at that time when he met Pilar on the other side. In one tender moment, he touched both their backs and stepped aside as Pilar drew her sons to herself at midfield. They staged their own celebration after taking pictures as the day ended with triumph when Colorado thrashed Oklahoma State 52-0 in the last home game.The Sanders family story is all about progress and hardship. Deion wed Pilar in 1999 when he was still at the top of his game, setting the stage for the couple to have three children: Shilo, Shedeur, and Shelomi. The relationship fell on hard times and led to a very public divorce in 2013. Custody disputes and legal battles ensued in which Deion initially had custody of the children. Later, in 2017, Pilar got legal custody of Shedeur and Shelomi, although Deion remained a significant parent in his children's lives, especially now as Shedeur's head coach at Jackson State and currently Colorado.Divorce brought with it allegations and legal tussles. While Pilar has challenged the validity of their prenuptial agreement and sought greater financial support, Deion has staged an assault with defamation litigation, claiming reputational damage following judgment in court in favor of Deion for lack of any proof justifying her claims.Also Read: Washington Commanders hire Mark Clouse as team president, signaling a new era of leadership In the midst of all the personal struggles, Deion Sanders found solace in his faith, and after that entire ordeal, he was open about being a Christian after the very first time he got divorced. Recently, in an episode of Bear Grylls' Running Wild, he spoke about how devotion to Christ indeed shaped his life and also caught the highlights of his relationships. This spiritual grounding appears to have played a role in fostering resilience and unity within his family, as seen during Shedeur’s heartfelt senior day celebration—a moment that transcended past conflicts and showcased the enduring bond between parents and children.

Loud taunts, players heckled during Team India nets in Adelaide

WATCH:

Virat Kohli back among the runs with a solid hundred vs Australia in Perth

NEW DELHI: Virat Kohli 's incredible fitness and consistency continue to be the cornerstone of his cricketing success. He recently ended his long century drought by scoring his 30th Test century in India's commanding 295-run victory over Australia in the first match of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy in Perth.While fans marvel at the 36-year-old's ability to maintain peak performance, his wife, actor Anushka Sharma , has shed light on the secret behind his remarkable fitness.In a video that has gone viral on social media ahead of the Pink Ball Test in Adelaide, Anushka spoke about Kohli's unwavering commitment to his health and lifestyle. "Let me be very honest about it, Virat is incredibly disciplined about his health and fitness. I think this is also happening in our industry now," she said, emphasizing his role as a trailblazer in healthy living.Anushka revealed the daily habits that have helped Kohli sustain his level of excellence over the years. "Every morning without fail, he is up early doing cardio or HIIT, and practicing cricket with me. His diet is clean - no junk food or sugary drinks. Can you believe he hasn't eaten butter chicken in almost 10 years?"She also stressed how essential rest is in Kohli's routine. "Sleep is non-negotiable for him. He ensures he gets enough rest. It's the key to staying sharp and performing at his best. He always says - that is something you have control over."Anushka concluded by highlighting what sets Kohli apart. "His commitment to every aspect of his lifestyle is what makes him not just a world-class athlete, but also an inspiration to everyone around him."Kohli's discipline has been instrumental in bouncing back from a recent dip in form. His century in Perth marked his tenth against Australia Down Under, placing him just one short of Sir Donald Bradman 's record for centuries against the same opposition away from home - 11 vs England.As India prepare for the crucial Pink Ball Test starting Friday in Adelaide, Kohli's fitness and form will play a pivotal role in the team's quest to secure a spot in the World Test Championship final at Lord's next year.

Rishabh Pant created history at the IPL 2025 Auction, becoming the most expensive player in the league's history. The dynamic left-handed wicketkeeper-batter was snapped up by Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) for a record-breaking Rs 27 crore. Pant's credentials as a proven match-winner and natural leader made him LSG's obvious choice to spearhead their campaign.For a brief moment, Shreyas Iyer held the title of the most expensive IPL player after Punjab Kings secured his services for Rs 26.75 crore. Iyer, who led Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) to the championship last season, was a hot commodity at the auction following his release by KKR.While Pant and Iyer were expected to fetch eye-watering bids, the third-highest bid of the IPL 2025 Auction was a surprise. KKR made headlines by bringing back Venkatesh Iyer for Rs 23.75 crore, highlighting their commitment to retaining their core players.Another standout moment of the two-day auction was the signing of 13-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi. Starting with a base price of Rs 30 lakh, the teenager became a sensation when Rajasthan Royals secured him for Rs 1.10 crore, making him one of the youngest players to ever feature in the IPL.Out of the national team setup for over two years, Bhuvneshwar Kumar’s experience found high demand among IPL franchises, with Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) securing his services for Rs 10.75 crore on Monday.The second day of the mega auction turned out to be lucrative for several Indian pacers, while some big names, including Shardul Thakur, Prithvi Shaw, Ajinkya Rahane, Kane Williamson, and Glenn Phillips, went unsold.Set to turn 35 before the start of the next IPL season, Bhuvneshwar boasts an impressive record of 300 wickets in 287 T20 matches with an economy rate under eight.Other notable deals included Deepak Chahar, who fetched Rs 9.25 crore from Mumbai Indians despite his injury history, and Mukesh Kumar, retained by Delhi Capitals for Rs 8 crore through the RTM card. Lucknow Super Giants also invested heavily, signing Test pacer Akash Deep for Rs 8 crore.Among the all-rounders, Krunal Pandya earned Rs 5.75 crore from RCB, who were in need of an experienced spin-bowling all-rounder. Rajasthan Royals made significant bids for Tushar Deshpande (Rs 6.50 crore) and Nitish Rana (Rs 4.20 crore), while Delhi Capitals secured former RCB skipper Faf du Plessis at a bargain base price of Rs 2 crore. Gujarat Titans acquired Washington Sundar for Rs 3.20 crore in another smart move.The scarcity of quality Indian seam-bowling all-rounders worked in favor of South Africa’s Marco Jansen, who secured a Rs 7 crore deal with Punjab Kings. Also making a major gain was veteran New Zealand pacer Trent Boult who was bought by Mumbai Indians for Rs 12.5 crore -- highlighting the demand for quality fast bowlers.Meanwhile, the auction reflected the high demand for Indian talent despite the limited options, ensuring lucrative deals for even fringe players.On Sunday, the first day of the auction, most of the high-profile names raked in the moolah as the franchises virtually emptied their pockets to bag the priority players in their respective shortlist.Led by Rs 27 crore Lucknow Super Giants spent to buy star wicketkeeper-batter Rishabh Pant, the sum of money splurged by the franchises came to a whopping INR 467.95 crore.Pant edged past Shreyas Iyer, who fetched Rs 26.75 crore from Punjab Kings, as teams went all out for marquee Indian stars. Venkatesh Iyer took home a whopping Rs 23.75 crore from KKR.A total of 84 players from the roster of 577 were presented on the opening day at the Abadi Al Johar Arena. Out of these 68 got sold, while four were retained through the Right-to-Match card.Among other big buys, leg-spinner Yuzvendra Chahal attracted Rs 18 crore from Punjab Kings, who also used the Right-to-Match card to bring back paceman Arshdeep Singh for Rs 18 crore. KL Rahul was picked up by Delhi Capitals for Rs 14 crore.Meanwhile, the BCCI has taken a significant step by announcing the schedules for the IPL for the next three seasons. This is a departure from the usual practice of releasing schedules closer to the tournament.The 2025 IPL will commence on March 14 and conclude on May 25.The IPL Auction 2025 showcased a dramatic and competitive bidding war, with several franchises securing high-profile talent to strengthen their squads for the upcoming season. The second day saw Indian pacer Bhuvneshwar Kumar topping the chart with a hefty price of INR 10.75 crore, reflecting the high demand for experienced fast bowlers despite his long absence from the national team. This influx of Indian talent demonstrates how IPL franchises value local players, often resulting in hefty bids even for those not part of the national setup.Franchises made smart moves by picking up key players based on specific team needs. Deepak Chahar, for example, fetched Rs 9.25 crore despite a history of injuries, highlighting the increasing reliance on proven seamers. Meanwhile, Mumbai Indians, who often make shrewd investments, secured both Mukesh Chahar and Deepak Chahar, bolstering their pace attack for IPL 2025. Lucknow Super Giants also impressed with strategic buys like Akash Deep, further reinforcing their depth in bowling.Notably, there was also a surge in the prices of all-rounders like Krunal Pandya (Rs 5.75 crore) and Washington Sundar (Rs 3.20 crore), whose versatility adds immense value to their respective teams. This indicates that franchises are looking for players who can contribute with both bat and ball, especially in the high-pressure, multifaceted environment of the IPL.The auction was also marked by some surprising omissions. Players like Shardul Thakur, Prithvi Shaw, Ajinkya Rahane, and Kane Williamson, who are usually regarded as top performers, went unsold, pointing to the shifting dynamics of IPL team strategies. While these players' exclusion may have shocked fans, it underlined the intense competition for spots and the changing nature of what franchises are looking for in their squads.Overall, the 2025 auction was a testament to the evolving nature of IPL strategies—teams focused on a mix of experience, youth, and flexibility. As the season nears, fans can look forward to an exciting and unpredictable tournament, with new combinations and fresh talent ready to light up the IPL stage.
Article Summary: Bhuvneshwar Kumar, out of India's national team for two years, fetched a hefty Rs 10.75 crore from RCB in the IPL 2025 auction. Deepak Chahar and Mukesh Kumar also secured lucrative deals. Rishabh Pant became the most expensive player on Day 1, going to LSG for Rs 27 crore.

Article Title: Will Rohit Sharma open or not? Sunil Gavaskar on India's playing XI for Adelaide Test
Article Text:
Rohit Sharma, KL Rahul and Yashasvi Jaiswal

Loud taunts, players heckled during Team India nets in Adelaide

KL Rahul Press Conference ahead of 2nd Test

WATCH:

The ideal batting positions for Rohit Sharma, Shubman Gill

NEW DELHI: A buoyant Indian cricket team is set to face Australia in the second match of the ongoing Border-Gavaskar Trophy at the Adelaide Oval , starting Friday. Leading 1-0 in the five-match series after a dominant 295-run victory in Perth, India are looking to extend their lead in the Pink Ball Test .India's squad received a significant boost with the arrival of skipper Rohit Sharma , who missed the first Test due to the birth of his second child. In Rohit's absence, KL Rahul and Yashasvi Jaiswal opened the innings in Perth, putting together a record 201-run partnership in the second innings, a key factor in India's triumph.With Rohit's return, the Indian think tank now faces a dilemma over the batting order.During a discussion on Star Sports, former Indian captain Sunil Gavaskar shared his thoughts on the potential XI and where Rohit Sharma should bat."He [Rohit Sharma] opens the batting. Short square boundaries will suit his kind of batting," Gavaskar stated. "Rahul drops down to No.6, in place of Jurel. And at No.3, Shubman Gill comes in place of Devdutt Padikkal. That would be my XI."Gavaskar also weighed in on the bowling combination, suggesting changes based on the pitch conditions in Adelaide. "I would maybe look at Washington Sundar 's place. Nitish Reddy will have to stay because it's a pink-ball Test; he will be your fourth seamer, fourth bowler. Whether you want to bring in Ashwin or Jadeja, that's the call they have to take once they go and see what the pitch has on offer."When asked about concerns over Rohit Sharma's form, Gavaskar dismissed any apprehensions. "No, not at all. Somebody of his class and calibre - it doesn't matter at all. The first time he comes in, he can get a hundred just like that. No worries."With Rohit Sharma and Shubman Gill potentially making a return, India's playing XI in Adelaide will be closely watched as they look to solidify their lead in the series. The Pink Ball Test promises to be an exciting contest under the lights at the Adelaide Oval.
Article Summary: India lead Australia 1-0 in five-match Border-Gavaskar Trophy series. India won the first Test by 295 runs in Perth. Rohit Sharma returned to the squad after the birth of his second child. Former India captain Sunil Gavasker says Sharma should bat at No.6.

Article Title: Ailing Vinod Kambli offered help by 1983 World Cup heroes
Article Text:
...On condition that he checks into rehab first

MUMBAI: For the second time in months, a disturbing video emerged of former India batter Vinod Kambli . In August, cricket fans were stunned to see Kambli struggling to walk properly, when someone captured it on camera.On Tuesday, another video immediately went viral, where the 52-year-old was seen clutching his childhood friend, legendary cricketer Sachin Tendulkar 's hand, trying to continue making conversation with him when they met on stage in a rare public meeting between the two.They had congregated at Shivaji Park during a memorial ceremony for their childhood coach Ramakant Achrekar. Also gone viral is his muddled and incoherent speech in the tribute Kambli attempted for his beloved coach.Marcus Couto, childhood cricketing friend, clarified Kambli's r eaction on Tuesday. "He wasn't drunk or something. He hasn't touched a drop of alcohol for the past one year," Couto told TOI on Wednesday, "It's just that he became very emotional during his brief meeting with Sachin, who greeted him nicely on the stage. He was very enthusiastic about meeting Sachin and attending the function."It was a poignant moment. "I met him after many years. He got up and hugged me and called out: 'Samya!'" said former India and Mumbai wicketkeeper Sameer Dighe, "I couldn't see him in his present condition. I felt so bad. I had tears in my eyes.""We've played together for 14 y ears (for Mumbai), I pray to God to give him good health," added Dighe."He has severe, multiple health issues," Couto, a former First-Class umpire, revealed, "There's no point in him going for rehab - Kambli has already gone to rehab 14 times! Thrice we took him to a rehab in Vasai."After the first video emerged in August, revealing that Kambli has serious ailments, Couto and his brother Ricky visited Kambli at his Jewel Cooperative Society residence in Bandra.While many of his cricketing colleagues have long given up on Kambli due to his issues with alcohol addiction, Tuesday's viral video has moved members of India's 1983 World Cup winning team to help the left-hander. But there is a condition. Kambli's World Cup winning seniors want the man to be willing to help himself first."Kapil (Dev, captain of the 1983 team) has told me clearly that if he wants to go to rehab, then we are willing to help him financially. However, he has to check into rehab himself first," former India seamer Balwinder Singh Sandhu told TOI on Wednesday."Only if he does that, we are ready to foot the bill, irrespective of how long the treatment lasts," added Sandhu. The 1983 team had also come together to help former India opener and coach Anshuman Gaekwad for his cancer treatment.This 'offer to help' by the 1983 champions could well be the last one that Kambli could be receiving from the Indian cricketing circle. "Not many are willing to help him," rued Sandhu, "It is well known his troubles start and end with alcohol. Kapil has had a bad experience with him. He had helped him get a job as a cricket expert on a New Delhi news channel, but Kambli only showed up a couple of times and then just stopped. I've asked Nilesh (Kulkarni), Abey (Kuruvilla) and Paras (Mhambrey), all who have played with him, about what can be done to help him. They have all given up on him. I've known him and Sachin from the time they were just 12. Sadly, we are losing a fine cricketer."
Article Summary: Vinod Kambli seen trying to make conversation with Sachin Tendulkar at a memorial ceremony for their childhood coach Ramakant Achrekar. The 52-year-old has a history of alcohol addiction and has been to rehab 14 times. Members of India's 1983 World Cup winning team have offered to pay for his treatment if he goes to rehab.

Article Title: 'Who cares?': Travis Head brushes off Sunil Gavaskar's comments on Josh Hazlewood injury as 'funny'
Article Text:
Sunil Gavaskar and Travis Head

Loud taunts, players heckled during Team India nets in Adelaide

KL Rahul Press Conference ahead of 2nd Test

NEW DELHI: Australia's Travis Head has dismissed Indian legend Sunil Gavaskar 's remarks about Josh Hazlewood 's side strain injury, calling them “pretty funny” and suggesting they were an attempt to stir controversy after Australia's heavy defeat in the first Test against India in Perth.Hazlewood was ruled out of the second Test in Adelaide due to a side strain, but Gavaskar questioned the injury's timing in his column, hinting that the fast bowler might have been dropped for comments critical of the Australian batters during a media conference.Gavaskar labeled the development "strange" and "a mystery," drawing parallels to controversies from Indian cricket's past.Speaking on the Willow Talk podcast, Head downplayed the comments. "I was surprised at Sunny's comments. They were pretty funny," he said. "He's in the entertainment business as a few teams around the world would say. He's in the commentary team. If that makes it more fun for him, then go for it."Head brushed off the suggestion of any internal divide in the Australian team, adding, "Dropping 'Hoff' (Hazlewood) and throwing a couple of daggers and shooting across the bow, but who cares? It is what it is. Everyone is paid to have an opinion."Gavaskar had previously speculated that Hazlewood's absence might be linked to fallout from his remarks following Australia's dismal batting display in Perth, where they were bowled out for 104 in the first innings despite dismissing India for 150.After the match, Hazlewood had pointedly said, "You probably have to ask one of the batters that question," when queried about the team's failure to capitalise.
Article Summary: Travis Head dismisses Sunil Gavaskar's comments about Josh Hazlewood's injury. Head says the comments were "pretty funny" and suggested they were an attempt to stir controversy. Gavasksar had suggested that the fast bowler might have been dropped for comments critical of the Australian batters during a media conference.

Article Title: Team India's top Test performances at Adelaide Oval
Article Text:
Virat Kohli celebrates after reaching his century against Australia at Adelaide Oval on December 13, 2014. (Photo by Robert Cianflone/Getty Images)

Dravid & Agarkar pull off a heist (2003)

Sehwag & Sachin stand tall (Jan 2008)

The Virat specials (2011, 2014)

Pujara shapes India's win (Dec 2018)

The Adelaide Oval , one of cricket's most picturesque Test venues, has since 2000 been a happy hunting ground for India, the memorable Test win over Australia in the 2003-04 series standing out. While the ground is a true oval - straight boundaries are long and those on the square are short - the wicket has traditionally been Australia's best batting pitch in Tests.A look at some of India's top Test performances at the historic venue this century...In Test cricket, it has happened only a handful of times that a team has lost a Test after scoring more than 550 runs in the first innings.Powered by Ricky Ponting's magnificent 242, Australia amassed 556. Virender Sehwag (47 off 41 balls) and Aakash Chopra gave India a 66-run start. However, after Sachin Tendulkar (1) and skipper Sourav Ganguly (2) were dismissed early, India slipped to 83 for four. Two batting greats, Rahul Dravid and VVS Laxman came together then, and in a rerun of their famous, epic partnership which shaped India's famous triumph at the Eden Gardens in 2001, they put on a 303-run stand.Dravid's 233 and Laxman's 148 helped India score 523. Then, wiry paceman Ajit Agarkar , India's current chief selector, took six for 41 in a deadly 16.2 over spell to bowl Australia out for 196. With Dravid (72 not out) standing tall, India successfully chased down 230 in the fourth innings to record a four-wicket win.It was the fourth and final Test of an acrimonious series, marred by Monkeygate. India went into the match 1-2 down in the series.Making a comeback, Virender Sehwag scored 63, but it was a masterly 153 by Sachin Tendulkar, the legend enjoying a second wind of his epic career, which helped India put up 526. Australia replied with 563. In danger of losing the Test after losing wickets regularly and Dravid (11) having retired hurt, India needed someone to stand in the middle. Shedding his natural attacking style, Sehwag hit 151 off 236 balls, perhaps one of his finest hundreds, which helped India earn a hard-fought draw.Coming off scores of 44 & 75 in the third Test at Perth, Virat Kohli had done enough to justify his place in the XI. Come January 2012 in Adelaide, he announced his arrival as India's main batsman for the next decade, slamming his maiden Test hundred, a gallant 116 in the first innings. India lost that Test by 298 runs and were whitewashed 4-0 but were happy they had unearthed a batsman for the ages.Kohli the captain was born at the same venue in Dec 2014. With MS Dhoni unavailable for the first Test, Kohli was pitchforked to India's Test captaincy.Responding superbly, Kohli hit centuries in both the innings - 115 & 141 -joining the likes of Vijay Hazare and Sunil Gavaskar in achieving the rare feat in Australia.Forging an exciting partnership with head coach Ravi Shastri, Kohli made India an exciting unit, one that didn't hesitate while chasing 364 in the final innings. India folded up at 315 and lost that Test by 48 runs, but Kohli had managed to make a statement about how India would play Test cricket under him. Cheteshwar Pujara had endured a lean time on India's previous tour (in the 2014-15 season). However, in Adelaide in Dec 2018, Pujara proved he was a complete batsman, stroking a fine century (123) in India's first innings.Batting first, India collapsed to 127 for six, but Pujara stood firm, taking the score to 250 with his monumental 246-ball, 376-minute effort. In the second innings, the Saurashtra man became more of an 'immovable object', wearing the Aussie bowlers down with his 204-ball 71. After laying the foundation of India's exciting 16-run victory, Pujara was justifiably named the 'Player of the Match.'
Article Summary: The Adelaide Oval is one of cricket's most picturesque Test venues. The wicket has traditionally been Australia's best batting pitch in Tests. India have won a number of Test matches at the historic venue. Virat Kohli and Cheteshwar Pujara have both scored hundreds at the ground.

Article Title: Los Angeles Rams quarterback Matthew Stafford was listed as a full practice participant on Wednesday

Matthew Stafford gets full practice on Wednesday amid a lateral ankle sprain

Matthew Stafford was practicing well on a Wednesday while carrying a lateral ankle sprain. Coach Sean McVay confirmed that Stafford was not expected to have restrictions in practice. Article Title: FIDE World Championship: Human errors rule game 8 as Ding, Gukesh seem oblivious of pitfalls, settle for draw
Article Text:
Gukesh Dommaraju and Ding Liren. (Photo by Roslan Rahman/AFP via Getty Images)

Reigning champion Ding Liren and challenger D Gukesh swapped their roles within the unfolding drama -facing deep trouble and enjoying a potentially decisive advantage -in a heart-stopping passage of play. But they were playing, evaluating and deciding within human limitations and hence did not see it as precisely as computers and AI-backed smart Alecs.As a result, their eighth game of the World Chess Championship ended in a draw after 51 moves and four and half hours of a ding-dong battle in Singapore on Wednesday. It's 4-4 now in the 14-game match with Game Nine (Gukesh white) scheduled on Thursday before Friday's rest day.On the 26th move, Gukesh, playing black, had a chance to press the advantage towards conversion with the move Nc5. The Indian challenger moved the knight to c5 but sadly, it was the wrong knight. Instead of the dfile knight, he moved the a-file knight to that square.Four moves later, it was Ding's turn to return the favour. He also needed to move his knight to e1 to cash in on the window offered by Gukesh. The Chinese did move this knight but pushed it forward to d4.The crazy turn of events continued on the 41st move too. Despite surviving the unpleasant position, Gukesh refused to go for the three-fold repetition and decided to play on. As he confessed later, he was not aware that he was closer to losing moments before this phase, else he would have taken the draw at that point.On the other hand, after falling to the trap of 22.Rb1, b5, and losing an extra pawn in the bargain, Ding was struggling to attain equality as Gukesh's 'a' and 'b' file pawns turned potent with the possible tactics of exchange sacrifice coming into play. And as he was preparing to calculate Gukesh's seemingly winning option of 26....Ndc5 over the board, the Indian played the other knight move mentioned above. Hence, even Ding was not aware that he would have been in serious trouble.Subsequently, Ding had the chance to capitalise on Gukesh's badly placed knight -pinned on c5 square. Moving that knight would have exposed his queen and rook to the opponent's bishop and rook respectively. But capitalising on that warranted a longterm plan. Human Ding failed to spot the computer-cooked retreat of his own knight (31.Ne1).Despite all that above, the game was not a comedy of errors. Far from it. There were no blunders, just minor inaccuracies that had a big impact. The overall quality of the precise play was of high level.The script largely went as per the earlier trend of the match -Gukesh surprised Ding in the opening (7...f6), this time with black pieces -the Chinese consumed a lot of time and barely equalised. Then the Indian enjoyed the advantage but could not find flawless lines. He lost his clock advantage too. For a change, he offered Ding a good chance too before sticking to his script of wanting to play in a tricky endgame. It involved queen, knight vs queen, rook with opposite coloured bishops and an extra pawn (5 vs 4) with high stakes.The fifth successive draw of the match thus travelled through a myriad of emotions.Ding jumped to English Opening (1.c4) but he fell half hour behind the clock within the first 10 moves. The pawn design and overall structure of the position soon took a crazy look.Gukesh had apparently won a blitz game against Arjun Erigaisi in this opening (without 7... f6) with black pieces in 'Warsaw' in May this year. There was no question of a draw 'pact' in Singapore though.In a crazy turn of events, Ding didn't move any of his central pawns (in 'd' and 'e' file) for the first 18 moves as he activated his bishops through the knight-file. Thus, the principle of pawns taking control of the centre of the board was not followed. When the draw was agreed, his pawn remained on the starting 'e2' square. Such instances are rare in high-level chess. When Max Euwe beat Alexander Alekhine in the 1935 World Championship match, they had played a 16-move draw in the 18th game. There, Euwe had moved his 'd' pawn after 12 moves with 'e' pawn being stationary.
Article Summary: Reigning champion Ding Liren and challenger D Gukesh swapped their roles within the unfolding drama -facing deep trouble and enjoying a potentially decisive advantage. But they were playing, evaluating and deciding within human limitations and hence did not see it as precisely as computers and AI-backed smart Alecs. Their eighth game of the World Chess Championship ended in a draw after 51 moves and four and half hours of a ding-dong battle in Singapore. It's 4-4 now in the 14-game match with Game Nine (Gukesh white) scheduled on Thursday before Friday's rest day.

Article Title: Manolo's Goa hand Hyderabad third consecutive defeat
Article Text: HYDERABAD: FC Goa made their coach Manolo Marquez 's 100th Indian Super League (ISL) game a memorable one as they routed Hyderabad Football Club 2-0 for their fourth straight victory, at the GMC Balayogi Stadium on Wednesday.The visitors scored through Udanta Singh (33rd minute) and Iker Guarrotxena Vallejo (44th) to jump to third on the table with 18 points. Article Title: "Chiefs are so dangerous": Tom Brady highlighted the key factor that makes the Chiefs the most formidable contenders for the Super Bowl
Article Text:

Tom Brady effectively explained why the Chiefs are still dangerous this season

Tom Brady is watching closely as Patrick Mahomes could soon be seen as the best player in NFL history . The Kansas City Chiefs are looking to win three Super Bowl titles in a row in 2024, starting a new NFL dynasty . However, recently, the Chiefs are not seen as the top favorite because of their up-and-down performance lately, with experts naming the Bills or Lions as the stronger teams, with Brady reminding everyone of this.The Chiefs have a record of 11-1 this year, leading to whispers that they might have made a deal with dark forces or are under some special "Tayvoodoo" charm. Fox analyst Tom Brady dismissed the idea that the Kansas City victories are just from luck or good chance.“To win the close games is always the mark of a really good team, to win when you’re not playing your best football is the mark of a very good team,” Brady told Colin Cowherd on Tuesday. “I just think the Chiefs are so dangerous because if it’s a one-score game in the fourth quarter and Patrick has the ball, he’s incredible… He’s so dangerous because then he has four downs late in the game where you gotta stop him for four downs, not three.He further added, “Patrick is going to manage the game so well, he’s going to throw to the open guy, he’s got Travis out there that is going to make the right decisions in the big moments like we’ve seen time and time again. Article Title: 'Jay Shah has the opportunity to take cricket to another level but without making it under the yoke of India': Outgoing ICC chair Greg Barclay
Article Text:
Jay Shah (L) became ICC chair on December 1 with Greg Barclay (R) stepping down.

If PCB doesn't accept hybrid model, Champions Trophy could be played outside of PAK, without PAK

The Telegraph

On congested calendar

'Not the Afghanistan board's fault'

Greg Barclay , who made way for Jay Shah as the International Cricket Council (ICC chairperson on December 1, believes the former Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) secretary has it in him to help the sport grow and reach the “another level”. However, he added that Shah must take all members together on this journey and not keep it "under the yoke of India."Barclay, who was ICC chair for four years from 2020, said the Indian cricket team and BCCI under Shah’s leadership can use their influence to grow the game globally and benefit growing nations.“I think he (Shah) has got a great opportunity to use what he’s got in his background to help India take the game to another level, but without making it sort of under the yoke of India as well,” Barclay was quoted as saying by“We’re really lucky to have India, they’re a massive contributor to the game across all the measures, but one country having that amount of power and influence does distort a whole lot of other outcomes, which is not necessarily helpful in terms of that global growth.”“There are a number of things that India could do to help unite and grow the game, including commercially helping to pool off-shore rights, using their teams to give opportunity to smaller full members and emerging countries, using their clout to open new territories and markets, collaborating closely with the ICC to help benefit members, as examples,” he said.Barclay, who stepped down from his role on December 1, in the midst of an ongoing crisis over the 2025 ICC Champions Trophy, admitted there was plenty of cricket being played that he had lost track of the calendar.In his tenure of two terms of two years each, three major franchise-based T20 leagues popped up, in the USA, the UAE and South Africa, further busying an already packed calendar. He blamed the members' self-interest for the situation."I reckon, gee, I'm at the apex of the game and I can't tell you who's playing around the world. In fact, I didn't realise that Sri Lanka were in South Africa until I read about Marco Jansen's seven wickets this morning," Barclay said. "So we've lost perspective. It's not great for the game at all. It's a mess. The calendar is incredibly congested and self-interest is such that it's almost impossible to untangle all of that, because no one's going to give up their content."The Canadian-New Zealand sports administrator also defended the governing body's decision not to sanction Afghanistan’s Full Membership status for Afghanistan Cricket Board not fielding a women's team. Fielding a women's team is integral to getting Full Membership with the ICC."It is not the Afghanistan board's fault. They used to have women's cricket. I think our approach has been right," he said. "It would be easy to kick Afghanistan out, but their board haven't done anything wrong. They're just working under a decree and a series of laws that says this is what you have to do. I don't think it would make a jot of difference to the ruling party there to kick them out."Maybe I'm a little naïve, but I think cricket is such a force for good there, and it brings a lot of joy to a lot of people. It is better to leave it there and hope that it can foster a bit of a change."He did point to the double standards of the national cricket boards, such as Cricket Australia, who have cancelled multiple bilateral series with Afghanistan but have played them at ICC events."If you really want to make a political statement, don't play them in a World Cup. Sure, it might cost you a semi-final place, but principles are principles. It's not about having half a principle."
Article Summary: Greg Barclay steps down as International Cricket Council (ICC) chair on December 1. Barclay believes Jay Shah has it in him to help the sport grow and reach the “another level” He added that Shah must take all members together on this journey and not keep it "under the yoke of India"

Article Title: Border-Gavaskar Trophy: Pink venom: Can D/N Test break trend of early finishes?
Article Text:
India Test squad training session at Adelaide Oval. (Photo by Mark Brake/Getty Images)

India vs Australia, 2nd Test: Facing the Pink Ball has different set of challenges for batters

Sold-out seats, and 6 mm grass

Spin factor and other tricks, and thunderstorms too!

ADELAIDE: Damian Hough offers a sheepish smile when asked about the drop-in pitch debacle in New York during the T20 World Cup earlier this year.The Adelaide Oval curator, whose team was in charge of preparing those fresh surfaces, now has an even more important task at hand -he must ensure the second Test between India and Australia doesn't end in a heap of quick wickets and lead to similar accusations of farce."Both the drop-in pitches are challenging, we'll leave it at that," he offered. "New York was a great opportunity to get over there and learn. Anything you do in such a short time keeps you awake at night. But there's nothing bigger than India and Australia in a Test match."The brief sample size of pink-ball Tests, played only since Nov 2015, makes it difficult for the experienced curator to offer an educated guess on the expected duration of the game. One thing, though, is clear: these games, cooked up to draw in the evening crowd to the longer format, tend to finish quicker.The general perception that pink-ball affairs are a nightmare for batters is spot on, since of the 22 pink-ball Tests played, only six have lasted the full distance of five days. Seven have ended within four days, seven within three days and two games within two days, in Ahmedabad (2021) and Port Elizabeth (2017).Maybe it's because the seam, or the ball itself, can be difficult for batters to spot, or perhaps because it jags around in the in-between twilight hours with the lights on, or even because of the early swing. Also, the jury is still out on the lacquer on the ball.It's also clear truncated pink-ball Tests are not limited to the hard and bouncy surfaces of Australia, or Adelaide in particular. In fact, Adelaide isn't particularly notorious - out of seven games, two have lasted the duration. There have also been two three-day finishes and three four-day affairs.Of the last seven pink-ball Tests played across the world, only the 2021 Adelaide game between Australia and England has been played across five days. But it was also here that Australia rolled India over for 36 in Dec 2020, with fast bowler Josh Hazlewood , who is sitting this game out, taking 5/8 in India's second innings."Back in the day, Adelaide was known for bat-a-thons and draws," Hough said. "Do you want a five-day draw out of it? Obviously not. But do you want a two-and-a-half-day game? No, you don't. Wickets falling can be exciting, but 10 wickets and 300 runs would be ideal. You've got to get that balance right. The fans come (tickets are sold out at the 53,500-seat stadium). We play our role, but the players play the game at the end of the day."Nearly 6 mm of grass has been left on the pitch, the same as in the '36 all out' Test. A recent Shield game between South Australia and Western Australia saw the quicks call the shots. "The preparation is the same," Hough said. Pacers have picked up 106 of the 134 wickets to fall in the day-night Tests here, with spinners picking up 28.In fact, spin could even come into play later on, according to Hough, because of the 30% clay content, which tends to break up. "Also, if you don't get a new ball under lights and you have set batters out there, you could see through the night-time period," he said."It's a pretty standard wicket," lamented Australia's star spinner Nathan Lyon . "I didn't expect this from Damian. We're going to challenge the defence for a long period of time. I really enjoy bowling here, with the spin and the bounce. Red ball, pink ball, white ball, definitely my favourite ground. It's a great venue to bowl spin. If you're good with the bat, you'll score runs." KL Rahul , for one, wasn't so sure about that. "The ball seems a bit harder than the red ball. While fielding, you can feel the ball hit your hands a lot quicker and harder. Same while batting. It seems to get to you much quicker and seams around a bit more than the red ball. There'll be a lot of seam movement. Picking the ball from the hand can be tricky."There are also thunderstorms predicted on the opening day, adding to the great unknowns of the pink-ball contest.
Article Summary: Adelaide Oval curator Damian Hough says drop-in pitches are 'challenging' Only six of the 22 pink-ball Tests played have lasted the full distance of five days. Seven have ended within four days, seven within three days and two games within two days.

Article Title: Border-Gavaskar Trophy: The new KL Rahul, open to modification
Article Text:
KL Rahul. (Photo by Paul Kane/Getty Images)

India's eternal floater doesn't worry about his batting position anymore. Make him open or slot him in the middle,

's ready to roll. Australia is where it all began for him, all he needs now is a chance to contribute...

KL Rahul Press Conference ahead of 2nd Test

ADELAIDE: As Rohit Sharma and Yashasvi Jaiswal sweated it out under the blazing South Australian sun, batting as a pair in the pace nets, a composed KL Rahul took fresh guard against the sidearm throwers alongside. Minutes earlier, Rahul had been reminiscing about Australia being the place where it all began for him as a Test opener.Back on the 2014-15 tour - made famous by Virat Kohli 's twin Adelaide tons and MS Dhoni's shock retirement from the format - the then-22-year-old Rahul's Test debut in Melbourne had been a forgettable one.He was slotted in at No. 6 first up and managed three off eight balls, falling to a streaky attempt at slog sweeping Nathan Lyon and managing only a top edge. In his second dig he was pushed up to No. 3 and fell in equally horrifying fashion, another top edge to a short one from Mitchell Johnson costing him his wicket. Luckily, by the next Test in Sydney, his nerves had started to settle.Pushed up to open, Rahul came up with a composed 262-ball 110, keeping the demons at bay with discipline and verve to announce his arrival. And this has been his rollercoaster story ever since, with crests following troughs and long absences in-between some stellar performances, especially away from home in challenging conditions.Even a decade on, he remains the eternal floater in India's batting order, with even the disciplined and match-winning contribution in Perth in the first Test of this series offering no guarantee of a settled spot."Luckily for me, I've batted in different positions. Early on, it was a bit of a challenge mentally, how to play those first 20-25 balls. Not so much technique, but what shots to play, how early I can attack, how cautious I need to be.Those were a bit tricky early on. But now that I've played in ODIs, Tests and all over the place, it's given me a little bit of an idea how I need to manage my innings. It's the start that's important, whether I'm batting at the top or middle. The first 30-40 balls. If I can manage that, everything else starts to seem like regular batting."Ten years ago, it was my first Test series. It was a bit surreal. There was a lot going on in my head. I've learnt a lot. I'm looking forward to the next 10 years and Australia is where it all started for me," Rahul said.In India's remarkable Perth win a few days ago, Rahul - opening for the first time since Feb 2023 - chewed up 74 balls as India collapsed for 150 in 298 balls in their first innings. He then stayed put for 176 balls in a 201-run opening stand as Jaiswal scored 161."I was told quite early (to open). I missed out in the New Zealand series, so I was told to be ready. I had enough time to prepare. I've batted enough at the top of the order and know what processes I need to follow," Rahul said.However, with captain Rohit back and No. 3 Shubman Gill having recovered from his finger injury, could Rahul be shoved down the order again? If yes, it's only to be expected, since Rohit has ruled the opening slot since 2019. If not, it may well be the start of a fresh chapter again in Australia."This is my first pink-ball Test , so I'll try and face up to whatever comes my way," he said. "I just want to go out there, bat and play for the team. I just want to be in the playing XI. Fit me in wherever."The person holding the key is captain Rohit, who batted at No. 4 in the practice game in Canberra, keeping Jaiswal and Rahul's opening slots intact. So maybe Rahul has been told where he'll bat? The answer was equivocal. "I've been told, but I've also been told not to share it. You'll have to wait for Day One or maybe when the captain comes here tomorrow."
Article Summary: KL Rahul says Australia is where it all began for him as a Test opener. India's eternal floater doesn't worry about his batting position anymore. Make him open or slot him in the middle, he's ready to roll. The person holding the key is captain Rohit Sharma, who batted at No. 4 in Canberra.

Article Title: Rohit Sharma’s tips for fans ahead of the Adelaide Test match
Article Text:
Rohit Sharma (Screengrab Photo)

Indian captain Rohit Sharma , who recently joined the team after missing the first Test in Perth, shared a moment with fans ahead of the crucial pink-ball day-night Test match in Adelaide.In a viral video, Rohit Sharma can be seen posing for photographs with a smile while interacting with his fans. Rohit, accompanied by T. Dilip, was entering a building when fans noticed the skipper and surrounded him for photos and autographs.Fans wished him luck, and the captain, with his cheerful nature, responded with a "thank you."One fan, struggling to get the angle right for a selfie, was met with a playful remark from the skipper: "Life mein ek hi opportunity milta hai, you have to grab it."The second Test of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy is set to begin on 6th December in Adelaide. This will be a pink-ball, day-night Test match. India has haunting memories of the day-night Adelaide Test , as the last time they played at this venue, they recorded their lowest-ever innings score—just 36 runs.After their dominant performance in the first Test in Perth, India will be high on confidence. However, Australia will be looking to bounce back in the series.In this five-match Test series, India is leading, making the second Test crucial for Australia to remain in contention.Australia will aim to avoid falling too far behind, especially after suffering defeats in their previous home series against India.
Article Summary: Indian captain Rohit Sharma recently joined the team after missing the first Test in Perth. The second Test of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy is set to begin on 6th December in Adelaide. India has haunting memories of the day-night Adelaide Test as the last time they played at this venue, they recorded their lowest-ever innings score.

Article Title: 13-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi stars as India march into U-19 Asia Cup semifinals
Article Text:
(Asian Cricket Council Photo)

India secured a dominant 10-wicket victory over the United Arab Emirates in their final Group A match of the U-19 Asia Cup in Sharjah on Wednesday. This win propelled them into the semi-finals.India will face Group B toppers Sri Lanka in the semi-finals. The other semi-final will see Group A leaders Pakistan take on Bangladesh on Friday.Pakistan and Sri Lanka came through the group stage undefeated, setting the stage for an exciting last-four clash.Thirteen-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi showcased his remarkable talent, living up to the expectations surrounding him.The UAE batted first but struggled, regularly losing wickets and ultimately being bowled out for a mere 137 runs in 44 overs.Yudhajit Guha , India's right-arm medium pacer, led the bowling attack with impressive figures of 3/15. Chetan Sharma and all-rounder Hardik Raj also contributed significantly, each taking two wickets for 27 and 28 runs, respectively.India comfortably chased down the target in just 16.1 overs, thanks to unbeaten half-centuries from openers Suryavanshi and Ayush Mhatre. Suryavanshi scored a quickfire 76 off 46 balls, while Mhatre contributed a steady 67 off 51 balls.Suryavanshi's recent acquisition by Rajasthan Royals at the IPL auction for Rs 1.10 crore, making him the youngest player ever in the IPL, added to the excitement surrounding his performance.The left-handed Suryavanshi's innings included three fours and six impressive sixes. Mhatre also displayed his power-hitting abilities, smashing four boundaries and four sixes.India's U-19 Asia Cup campaign began with a disappointing 43-run loss to arch-rivals Pakistan. They then bounced back strongly, thrashing Japan by a massive 211 runs.
Article Summary: India secured a dominant 10-wicket victory over the United Arab Emirates in their final Group A match of the U-19 Asia Cup in Sharjah on Wednesday. This win propelled them into the semi-finals. India will face Group B toppers Sri Lanka. The other semi-final will see Group A leaders Pakistan take on Bangladesh.

Article Title: PAK vs ZIM: Another clash with Zimbabwe, another record broken in Pakistan's cricket history
Article Text:
Sufiyan Muqeem (AP Photo)

Pakistan's wrist spinner, Sufiyan Muqeem , led his team to a resounding 10-wicket victory against Zimbabwe in the second T20I at Bulawayo, securing the series win. The match took place on Tuesday.Muqeem's exceptional spell of bowling saw him claim five wickets for just three runs in his four overs. Zimbabwe's innings rapidly unravelled as they were bowled out for a mere 57 runs in 12.4 overs. They had initially started promisingly.The 25-year-old’s remarkable figures are now the best ever recorded by a Pakistan bowler in T20I cricket. He surpassed Umar Gul 's previous record of 5 wickets for 6 runs. Gul achieved this feat twice, against New Zealand and South Africa.This five-wicket haul is Muqeem's first in T20Is, placing him in an exclusive group of Pakistani bowlers alongside Umar Gul and Imad Wasim Pakistan comfortably chased down the target in just 33 balls, reaching 61 without losing any wickets. Openers Saim Ayub (36) and Omair Yousuf (22) made light work of the chase. This victory followed their 57-run win in the first T20I on Sunday.Zimbabwe's opening batsmen, Brian Bennett (21) and Tadiwanashe Marumani (16), provided a solid start, putting on 37 runs for the first wicket in four overs. They were the only Zimbabwean batsmen to reach double figures.The dismissal of both openers within five balls triggered a dramatic collapse, with Zimbabwe losing their remaining wickets for only 20 runs. Muqeem’s devastating spell was the primary cause of this collapse.Marumani was caught by Tayyab Tahir at cover point, while Bennett was dismissed by Irfan Khan at deep square leg at Queens Sports Club.Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe's experienced all-rounder and often their key batsman, was dismissed for only three runs. Abbas Afridi bowled him, uprooting his off stump.Raza was one of the four Zimbabwean bowlers who struggled to contain Pakistan's opening batsmen, Ayub and Yousuf. The Pakistani openers struck ten boundaries, including a six each, during their short but effective partnership.Ayub's boundary past backward point sealed the comprehensive victory for Pakistan.The third and final T20I between Pakistan and Zimbabwe is scheduled for Thursday. Following this series, Pakistan will embark on an eight-match tour of South Africa. The tour will include matches across all formats, featuring two Test matches.
Article Summary: Sufiyan Muqeem took five wickets for just three runs in his four overs. Zimbabwe's innings rapidly unravelled as they were bowled out for a mere 57 runs in 12.4 overs. Pakistan comfortably chased down the target in just 33 balls.

Article Title: Sara Tendulkar joins Sachin Tendulkar Foundation as Director
Article Text:
Sara Tendulkar. (Pic Credit - X)

Loud taunts, players heckled during Team India nets in Adelaide

NEW DELHI: Legendary cricketer Sachin Tendulkar revealed on Wednesday that Sara Tendulkar , his daughter, has taken up the position of director at the Sachin Tendulkar Foundation (STF). Making the announcement on X, formerly Twitter, Sachin expressed his immense happiness about the development.Sara's new role focuses on strengthening the nation's capabilities in sports, healthcare, and education sectors."I'm overjoyed to share that my daughter Sara Tendulkar has joined the @STF_India as Director. She holds a Master's degree in Clinical and Public Health Nutrition from University College London. As she embarks on this journey to empower India through sports, healthcare, and education, it serves as a reminder of how global learning can come full circle," Tendulkar said.Sachin accumulated 34,357 runs while appearing in 664 international matches in his illustrious career, maintaining an average of 48.52. He holds the distinction of being the highest run-scorer in international cricket.His remarkable achievement includes 100 centuries and 164 half-centuries, the most in international cricket history. He stands alone as the only player to achieve a hundred international centuries.In ODIs, Sachin established numerous records, scoring 18,426 runs at an average of 44.83, including 49 centuries and 96 half-centuries. In Test cricket, he amassed 15,921 runs at an average of 53.78, comprising 51 centuries and 68 fifties.Sachin holds the record for highest runs in both cricket formats. He achieved two significant milestones by becoming the first cricketer to score a double century in ODIs and participate in 200 Test matches.Sachin was a member of the victorious Indian team that secured the ICC Cricket World Cup in 2011. Following his World Cup debut in 1992, his aspiration to win the prestigious trophy was realised in 2011 when India defeated Sri Lanka in the final.
Article Summary: Legendary cricketer Sachin Tendulkar reveals that his daughter Sara has taken up the position of director at his foundation. Sara's new role focuses on strengthening the nation's capabilities in sports, healthcare, and education sectors. Sachin holds the record for highest runs in both cricket formats.

Article Title: Opening or middle order? Ravi Shastri on Rohit Sharma's batting position in Adelaide
Article Text:
How a change in batting position could well help Rohit Sharma in Tests

The ideal batting positions for Rohit Sharma, Shubman Gill

Should India continue with KL Rahul-Yashasvi Jaiswal as openers?

NEW DELHI: India captain Rohit Sharma will return to lead the side in the second Test against Australia at Adelaide Oval starting Friday after missing the first match to spend time with his family for the birth of his second child.Following a strong opening partnership between KL Rahul and Yashasvi Jaiswal in the first innings of the first Test, the return of Rohit presents a selection dilemma for the team management. Will they stick with the Rahul-Jaiswal combination for the opening slot, or will Rahul make way for Rohit to open alongside Jaiswal?Former India head coach Ravi Shastri expressed his opinion on the matter saying the decision lies with Rohit, whether he chooses to open the batting or move to the middle order.Speaking on the ICC Review, Shastri highlighted the significance of Rohit's experience, noting that it could be a game-changer for India as they aim to take a 2-0 lead against an Australian side eager to level the series."It's a fantastic boost because there's no doubting his quality," Shastri said. "He's very experienced. You need that experience in the middle order."Rohit started his Test career in the middle order before transitioning to an opening role. In 41 innings at No. 5 or lower, he has scored 1,474 runs at an average of 43.35, including nine half-centuries and three centuries.While his best performances in the middle order have been at home, where he boasts an impressive average of 96.12, his record in Australia has been more modest. Rohit has managed 187 runs in seven innings at an average of 26.71, including a vital half-century in Melbourne during the 2018/19 series."It"s the right mix of experience and youth in the setup, so whether he opens the batting or goes in the middle order, the choice is his," Shastri said."He's experienced enough to see where he's most dangerous when it comes to Australia. Where would Australia not like to see him? That's the position he should choose. And he's the leader of the pack, so he can afford to do that."Shastri also pointed out KL Rahul's good form, highlighting his crucial 77 in the second innings in Perth, as another reason why Rohit should consider batting lower down the order."I think he (Rahul) should carry on (opening) because Rohit has not had much time since he's come here (Australia)," Shastri said."Very quickly he had to play that Prime Minister's XI game. But I would say carry on with the same setup. He [Rohit] can bat at five or six."
Article Summary: India captain Rohit Sharma will lead the side in the second Test against Australia. Sharma missed the first match to spend time with his family for the birth of his second child. Former India head coach Ravi Shastri says the decision lies with Rohit, whether he chooses to open the batting or move to the middle order.

Article Title: Ben Stokes asks for clarity on over-rate penalties: 'We would like more communication with the ICC'
Article Text:
England's Ben Stokes during the first Test against New Zealand in Christchurch. (AP)

What India need to do to qualify for World Test Championship final

England Test captain Ben Stokes voiced his concerns regarding the International Cricket Council 's communication with players about over-rate penalties. He believes the ICC should review its over-rate regulations for the World Test Championship .This follows penalties imposed on both England and New Zealand after the first Test match between the two sides. The match concluded within four days, yet both teams faced sanctions for slow over-rates.Each team lost three World Test Championship points. Players from both sides also received fines equivalent to 15% of their match fees.New Zealand's penalty dropped them from fourth to fifth place in the WTC standings. England's cumulative over-rate penalties in the current WTC cycle now total 22 points. Nineteen of those penalty points were incurred during the 2023 Ashes series."The most frustrating thing, from both teams' points of view, is that the game finished early, there was a result. But I think the frustration actually stems back to last year in the Ashes where it was the first time I really brought it up to the match referee and the umpires," said Stokes. "I guess the most frustrating thing is that it's always an issue depending on where you are in the world and the style of cricket that's played. There's never an over-rate issue in Asia because of how much spin is played."There's so many tactical decisions that you need to make, whether that be chatting with the bowler or field changes. As a captain, I like to change things quite a lot and the field could be completely different six balls in an over. But that's not taken into consideration. And getting told to just 'hurry up' isn't going to fix it, because we're out there playing a game. The times and the rules are the same wherever you go in the world. From a player's point of view - and I'm not the only one who shares this opinion - we would like to have a lot more communication with the ICC around this," opined Stokes.Stokes was particularly upset by the non-response from the ICC. He clarified he hadn't signed the over-rate chargesheet since the Lord's Test during the Ashes as a form of protest until he heard from the ICC, although he and New Zealand captain Tom Latham did accept the charges levelled against them in Christchurch."The two conversations I've had with the match referees have actually been very good and the match referees have handled it very, very well and been very understanding from a player's point of view. But it's been over a year now since I made some comments around the over rates and still to this day we're yet to hear any response back from anyone at the ICC around that," he said."I've not signed an over-rate sheet since Lord's in the Ashes just until we hear some communication back from the ICC that we're still waiting for. Captains have to sign over-rate sheets and fines and stuff, but I have said 'no' until I have the conversations. But they still take the fines off you anyway," lamented Stokes.
Article Summary: England captain Ben Stokes has voiced his concerns about over-rate penalties. He believes the ICC should review its over- rate regulations for the World Test Championship. This follows penalties imposed on both England and New Zealand after the first Test match between the two sides.

Article Title: Dhruv Parashar, Ethan D Souza, Farhan Khan, Aryan Lakra lead 12 UAE players picked by ILT20 franchises
Article Text: NEW DELHI: UAE star players Ethan D Souza , Aryan Lakra and Dhruv Parashar made headlines by earning selections in Season 3 Player Selection Process of the ILT20 in Dubai on Wednesday.Left-handed batter D Souza is set to represent the Sharjah Warriorz, while Parashar and Lakra will join the Desert Vipers and MI Emirates squads, respectively.Recently, Parashar showcased his skills for the Desert Vipers Development team at the ILT20 Development Tournament 2024, claiming five wickets. Meanwhile, Lakra made an impact for the Gulf Giants Development team, scoring 85 runs, including a vital half-century.The Abu Dhabi Knight Riders have picked Shahid Iqbal Bhutta and Ibrar Ahmed for their squad. Both players delivered standout performances at the ILT20 Development Tournament 2024.Bhutta, representing the ILT20 Pearls, claimed six wickets across seven innings, while Ibrar Ahmed impressed with six scalps in just four outings for the Dubai Capitals Development team.Khuzaima Bin Tanveer, who was part of the Desert Vipers Development squad, will be promoted to the main Vipers team, alongside Parashar. The Dubai Capitals have selected Farhan Khan and Zeeshan Naseer, recognizing their impressive performances with the ball in the Development Tournament, where they took 8 and 10 wickets, respectively.Meanwhile, Season 1 champions Gulf Giants have bolstered their squad by adding Muhammad Saghir Khan, following his strong showing for the Gulf Giants Development team. They have also signed Muhammad Uzair Khan, the leading wicket-taker in the ILT20 Development Tournament 2024, with 16 wickets, to further strengthen their lineup.Defending champions MI Emirates have reselected seasoned UAE pacer Zahoor Khan, following his stint with the ILT20 Pearls in the ILT20 Development Tournament 2024 that saw him pick up five wickets in just as many matches, with Lakra being their other pick.Former UAE captain Rohan Mustafa will represent the Warriorz with fellow southpaw Ethan D Souza. Rohan Mustafa will look to carry his strong form for the ILT20 Pearls in the ILT20 Development Tournament 2024 that earned him 149 runs in seven innings.With the UAE Player Selection Process wrapped up, the six squads ILT20 Season 3 are now set.
