Article Summary: UAE star players Ethan D Souza, Aryan Lakra and Dhruv Parashar made headlines by earning selections in Season 3 Player Selection Process of the ILT20 in Dubai on Wednesday. Left-handed batter Souza is set to represent the Sharjah Warriorz, while parashar and Lakra will join the Desert Vipers and MI Emirates squads, respectively.

Article Title: Nathan Lyon predicts Mitchell Marsh will bowl in Adelaide
Article Text:
Mitchell Marsh. (Cricket Australia Photo)

KL Rahul Press Conference ahead of 2nd Test

What India need to do to qualify for World Test Championship final

Australia's premier spin bowler Nathan Lyon expressed confidence in Mitchell Marsh 's bowling fitness for the second Test against India. However, Lyon also stated his willingness to bowl extra overs if needed.Marsh's fitness has been a concern for Australia leading up to the pink-ball Test, starting Friday. He experienced discomfort after bowling nearly 20 overs in the first Test loss to India.Australia added uncapped all-rounder Beau Webster to the squad as cover. However, it appears Marsh will likely retain his place in the playing eleven."I honestly think we'll see Mitch Marsh bowl," Lyon told reporters on Wednesday.Lyon isn't worried about Marsh's fitness. He praised Marsh's performance since returning to the team, particularly his dominant display during the Ashes series in England."I'm not concerned about Bison's fitness if I'm being honest. He's been brilliant for us since he's come back in. He came back in that game in Leeds during the Ashes and has really dominated, so got full confidence in Bison. Happy to bowl his overs."Lyon is accustomed to bowling alongside all-rounders like Mitchell Marsh and Cameron Green , or even both. He has also led the bowling attack when Australia opts for four specialist bowlers, with part-time support from the top order.Even without a dedicated all-rounder, Lyon regularly bowls extended spells, especially when he's the only spinner in a four-man attack. He understands his role within the team and is prepared to bowl more overs if required."I'm very clear on my role within the team. Nothing really changes with me…if I can get the opportunity to bowl more overs, I'll jump at it," he said.Lyon had a quiet first Test but anticipates spinners playing a bigger role in the second Test at the Adelaide Oval. He boasts an impressive record at the venue, with 63 wickets at an average of 25.26 in 13 matches, including seven day-night games.Lyon considers the Adelaide Oval an excellent venue for spinners. He praised the head curator, Damien Hough, for preparing a balanced pitch that challenges both batsmen and bowlers."I think it's a great, great venue to play spinner. And I think what Damien (head curator) does here is he produces a great wicket that got enough in it, and it's challenging for both bat and ball."Lyon believes the Adelaide Oval pitch offers opportunities for both batsmen and bowlers to excel. He considers it one of the best cricket wickets globally and anticipates it being conducive to spin bowling."If you are good enough with the bat, your score runs. If you good enough for the ball, you'll hopefully create a few chances along your way. This is probably the best cricket wicket in the world, if I'm being honest with you. So I'm expecting it to be pretty helpful to spin bowling as well."Australia suffered a heavy defeat in the first Test in Perth, trailing 0-1 in the five-match series. Lyon, however, expects Australia to rebound.He acknowledged that Australia didn't perform well in Perth and that India comprehensively outplayed them. He also found the intense reactions following the loss somewhat amusing, considering it's a five-match series."We've had a chance to reflect and we understand that we didn't play our best period in Perth and India, totally our player played us. But with all the other stuff, it's been quite humorous, in a way, looking at how much has been said and the reactions of so many different people after one loss, the beauty of a five test match test series, is we get the opportunity to turn that around."Lyon emphasized the opportunity to reverse their fortunes in the remaining Test matches. He recognizes India's strong performance in Perth but views it as a chance for Australia to bounce back."That's the challenge of what we face right now, obviously, coming up against a world class India side that played exceptional game of cricket in Perth, but that's been nine days ago now or so."
Article Summary: Australia's premier spin bowler Nathan Lyon expressed confidence in Mitchell Marsh's bowling fitness for the second Test against India. Lyon also stated his willingness to bowl extra overs if needed. Marsh's fitness has been a concern for Australia leading up to the pink-ball Test, starting Friday.

Article Title: Ollie Pope to continue as wicketkeeper as England name unchanged team for second New Zealand Test
Article Text:
Ollie Pope. (Pic Credit - X)

KL Rahul Press Conference ahead of 2nd Test

England playing XI: Zak Crawley, Ben Duckett, Jacob Bethell, Joe Root, Harry Brook, Ollie Pope (wicket-keeper), Ben Stokes (captain), Chris Woakes, Gus Atkinson,

,

Shoaib Bashir

.

NEW DELHI: England have retained Ollie Pope as their wicket-keeper for the second Test against New Zealand , maintaining an unchanged lineup after Jordan Cox's thumb injury during practice.Following Cox's injury setback, Pope will continue his wicket-keeping responsibilities despite Ollie Robinson 's arrival in New Zealand as a potential replacement. The team management has shown confidence in Pope's abilities behind the stumps.Pope, who normally plays as a middle-order batter, previously kept wickets when Ben Foakes was unwell in 2022. His performance in the first Test included two catches and a valuable 77-run contribution with the bat in the first innings.Having secured an eight-wicket victory in the opening Test, England will aim to clinch their first away Test series triumph in two years when they face New Zealand in Wellington on Friday.
Article Summary: England retain Ollie Pope as their wicket-keeper for the second Test against New Zealand. Jordan Cox suffered a thumb injury during practice. England secured an eight-wicket victory in the opening Test in Delhi. England will aim to clinch their first away Test series triumph in two years when they face New Zealand in Wellington on Friday.
